content: NAFLD grade II → Elevated AST/ALT, ferritin, low HDL, elevated LDL, mild insulin resistance
HDL low due to fatty liver, not arterial disease
High muscularity and high physical activity
Improve liver detox phases, mitochondrial fat oxidation, hepatic glucose handling.
Adjust macronutrient timing; increase fiber and plants; adjust fructose load.
Through nutrition, circadian alignment, and omega-3.
Actinic keratosis & ulcerated lesion require evaluation.

content: Even breath sounds bilaterally, well ventilated.
Alert and oriented; no neurological deficits.
Pupils equal, round, and reactive to light; extraocular movements intact.
Soft and depressible; non-tender to palpation; no masses.
Symmetrical; no signs of acute deep venous thrombosis; presence of
venous insufficiency changes with ochre dermatitis in the left lower limb;
distal pulses normal and symmetric; no pedal edema.
Normal coloration, adequate turgor. On the right temporal region, there is a
non-ulcerated actinic keratosis measuring approximately 1 × 1 cm.
In the posterior crease of the left ear, there is a 5 mm ulcerated lesion.

raw_lines: Even breath sounds bilaterally, well ventilated.
Alert and oriented; no neurological deficits.
Pupils equal, round, and reactive to light; extraocular movements intact.
Soft and depressible; non-tender to palpation; no masses.
Symmetrical; no signs of acute deep venous thrombosis; presence of
venous insufficiency changes with ochre dermatitis in the left lower limb;
distal pulses normal and symmetric; no pedal edema.
Normal coloration, adequate turgor. On the right temporal region, there is a
non-ulcerated actinic keratosis measuring approximately 1 × 1 cm.
In the posterior crease of the left ear, there is a 5 mm ulcerated lesion.

hs-CRP1.5 mg/L<1.0 optimalMild metabolic inflammation → consistent with

Mixed dyslipidemia driven by NAFLD, not by high cardiovascular risk.

structured_content.text: Normal sinus rhythm, with upright P waves in leads I, II, and aVF.
Rate appears within normal limits (~60–70 bpm).
Consistent P before every QRS and constant PR interval → normal AV conduction.
QRS duration: narrow → no bundle branch block.
QT interval: appears normal for heart rate.
Normal frontal plane axis; no deviation.
Good R-wave progression across precordial leads (V1–V6).
ST segments are isoelectric, without elevation or depression → no evidence of ischemia or infarction.
T waves are normal in morphology and distribution; no inversion or strain pattern.
No signs of pericarditis, electrolyte imbalance, or arrhythmogenic patterns.
No evidence of prior myocardial infarction, ischemia, arrhythmia, conduction abnormalities, or structural heart disease.

raw_lines: Normal sinus rhythm, with upright P waves in leads I, II, and aVF.
Rate appears within normal limits (~60–70 bpm).
Consistent P before every QRS and constant PR interval → normal AV conduction.
QRS duration: narrow → no bundle branch block.
QT interval: appears normal for heart rate.
Normal frontal plane axis; no deviation.
Good R-wave progression across precordial leads (V1–V6).
ST segments are isoelectric, without elevation or depression → no evidence of ischemia or infarction.
T waves are normal in morphology and distribution; no inversion or strain pattern.
No signs of pericarditis, electrolyte imbalance, or arrhythmogenic patterns.
No evidence of prior myocardial infarction, ischemia, arrhythmia, conduction abnormalities, or structural heart disease.

structured_content.text: The abdominal ultrasound shows moderate hepatic steatosis (grade II) with a mildly enlarged and heterogeneous
liver, but no focal lesions, no signs of chronic liver disease, and no evidence of fibrosis or cirrhosis.
The gallbladder is absent due to prior surgery, and the biliary ducts are normal.
The pancreas shows moderate fatty infiltration (lipomatosis), a common age-related finding, with no masses or
The spleen and kidneys are normal, except for a small simple renal cyst (10 mm) on the right kidney, which is benign
The aorta, retroperitoneum, and urinary bladder are normal.
The prostate is small and within normal size for his age (17.5 cc).
No free fluid, masses, or bowel abnormalities are seen.
The patient’s total coronary artery calcium (CAC) score is 15, which places him in the 31st percentile according to
MESA (Multi-Ethnic Study of Atherosclerosis) reference values for individuals of the same age, sex, and ethnicity.
A CAC score of 15 corresponds to a low atherosclerotic burden and indicates a low risk of coronary artery disease.
Most men his age have higher calcium levels, making this an overall favorable finding.
Calcium is limited to small, isolated areas in the LAD and LCx, with no calcification in the Left Main or RCA—an
This score reflects low coronary plaque burden and reduced probability of obstructive coronary artery disease.
Supports classification as low cardiovascular risk, especially when combined with his high fitness level and current
Ongoing risk factor management (blood pressure, lipid control, liver health, and lifestyle) remains appropriate.
According to current ACC/AHA guidelines, repeat CAC scoring is generally considered in 3–5 years, unless new

structured_content.subheading: At Sana Sana, we celebrate your commitment: we use health metrics to
guide the most effective steps, but we also understand that your well-being
goes far beyond the numbers. With your motivation and dedication, every
small achievement brings you closer to a longer, fuller life.
Together, we will turn healthy habits into everyday victories!
content: Improve Liver Health (Reverse NAFLD Grade II)

structured_content.subheading: Section 5: Complimentary Labs and Clinical References

content: Recording your goals allows you to measure your effort,
recognize your progress, and adjust your targets when necessary.
We recommend tracking this habit using any of the following methods:
Omega-3 (≤2 g/day) → mild increase in bleeding risk but still considered safe
Vitamin D (decreasing dose is advised anyway)
vitamin D level (81.8 ng/mL) is above the optimal range. Although not dangerously high, levels above 70–80 ng/mL
� Calcium buildup in the blood and kidneys
High vitamin D can lead to hypercalcemia, which may cause kidney stones, vascular calcification, and increased
Excess vitamin D increases calcium absorption, which the kidneys must filter, potentially stressing renal function over
� No added benefit at high levels
Studies show that vitamin D above 50–60 ng/mL does not provide extra immune or metabolic advantages. Higher
levels only increase risk, not benefit.
Keeping vitamin D in the optimal range (40–60 ng/mL) supports bone, immune, and metabolic health without
I recommend an omega-3 supplement that provides 1 gram of combined EPA and DHA per day, and not more than 2
Nordic Naturals Ultimate Omega Soft Gels
Sports Research Omega-3 Fish Oil (Triple Strength)
